sen.j: 尾崎 紅葉（おざき こうよう、慶応3年12月16日 (旧暦)（1868年1月10日） - 明治36年（1903年）10月30日）は、日本の小説家。
sen.e: Koyo OZAKI (December 16, 1867 (old lunar calendar) (January 10, 1868) - October 30, 1903) was a Japanese novelist.
Koyo OZAKI (December 16, 1867 (old lunar calendar) (January 10, 1868) - October 30, 1903) was a Japanese novelist.
Koyo OZAKI (January 10, 1868 - October 30, 1903) was a Japanese novelist.
sen.cmt: 旧暦部分を削除しました。

sen.j: 本名、徳太郎。
sen.e: His real name was Tokutaro.
His real name was Tokutaro.
His real name was Tokutaro.

sen.j: 「縁山」「半可通人」「十千万堂」などの号も持つ。
sen.e: He also had pen names such as Enzan, Hankatsujin, and Tochimando.
He also had pen names such as Enzan, Hankatsujin, and Tochimando.
He also had pen names such as 'Enzan', 'Hankatsujin', and 'Tochimando.'

sen.j: 江戸生れ。
sen.e: He was born in Edo.
He was born in Edo.
He was born in Edo.

sen.j: 帝国大学国文科中退。
sen.e: He dropped out of the department of Japanese literature, the Tokyo Imperial University.
He dropped out of the department of Japanese literature, Tokyo Imperial University.
He dropped out of the department of Japanese literature, Tokyo Imperial University.

sen.j: 明治18年（1885年）、山田美妙らと硯友社を設立し「我楽多文庫」を発刊。
sen.e: In 1885, he founded the Kenyusha with Bimyo YAMADA and others and published "Garakuta Bunko" (Library of Mixtures).
In 1885, he founded Kenyusha with Bimyo YAMADA and others and published "Garakuta Bunko" (Library of Mixtures).
In 1885, he founded Kenyusha with Bimyo YAMADA and others and published 'Garakuta Bunko' (Library of Mixtures).

sen.j: 『二人比丘尼 色懺悔』で認められ、『伽羅枕』『多情多恨』などを書き、幸田露伴と並称され明治期の文壇の重きをなした。
sen.e: His novel "Ninin bikuni irozange" (Amorous Confessions of Two Nuns) was well received, followed by Kyara makura (Pillow of Aloe) and Tajo takon (Full of Love, Full of Regret), and these works made Ozaki as a prominent figure in the literary circle in the Meiji Period of equal importance to Rohan KODA.

His novel "Ninin bikuni irozange" (Amorous Confessions of Two Nuns) was well received, followed by Kyara makura (Pillow of Aloe) and Tajo takon (Full of Love, Full of Regret), and these works made Ozaki a prominent figure in literary circles during the Meiji Period equal in importance to Rohan KODA.

His novel "Ninin bikuni irozange" (Amorous Confessions of Two Nuns) was well received, followed by "Kyara makura" (Pillow of Aloe) and "Tajo takon" (Full of Love, Full of Regret), and these works made Ozaki a prominent figure in literary circles during the Meiji Period equal in importance to Rohan KODA.
sen.cmt: 原文『 』の部分に" "を付加しました。

sen.j: 明治30年（1897年）から『金色夜叉』を書いたが、未完のまま没した。
sen.e: He started writing "Konjiki Yasha" (The golden demon) in 1897 but died unfinished.
He started writing "Konjiki Yasha" (The golden demon) in 1897 but died leaving it unfinished.
He started writing "Konjiki Yasha" (The golden demon) in 1897 but died leaving it unfinished.

sen.j: 泉鏡花、小栗風葉、柳川春葉、徳田秋声など、優れた門下生がいる。
sen.e: He had many excellent disciples such as Kyoka IZUMI, Fuyo OGURI, Shunyo YANAGAWA, and Shusei TOKUDA.
He had many excellent disciples such as Kyoka IZUMI, Fuyo OGURI, Shunyo YANAGAWA, and Shusei TOKUDA.
He had many excellent disciples such as Kyoka IZUMI, Fuyo OGURI, Shunyo YANAGAWA, and Shusei TOKUDA.

sen.j: 俳人としても角田竹冷らとともに、秋声会を興し正岡子規と並んで新派と称された。
sen.e: As a haiku poet, he founded Shuseikai with Chikurei KAKUTA and others, and regarded as a new school of haiku poets along with Shiki MASAOKA.
As a haiku poet, he founded Shuseikai with Chikurei KAKUTA and others, that was regarded as a new school of haiku poets along with Shiki MASAOKA.

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 慶応3年12月16日（1868年1月10日）、江戸（現東京都）芝中門前町（現在の浜松町）に生れる。
sen.e: Koyo was born on December 16, 1867 (old lunar calendar) (January 10, 1868) in Shibachumonmaecho (present-day Hamamatsucho), Edo (Tokyo).
Koyo was born on December 16, 1867 (old lunar calendar) (January 10, 1868) in Shibachumonmaecho (present-day Hamamatsucho), Edo (Tokyo).
Koyo was born on January 10, 1868 in Shibachumonmaecho (present-day Hamamatsucho), Edo (Tokyo).
sen.cmt: 旧暦部分を削除しました。

sen.j: 父は根付師の尾崎谷斎（惣蔵）、母は庸。
sen.e: His father was a netsuke (miniature carving attached to the end of a cord hanging from a pouch) artisan Kokusai (Sozo) OZAKI and mother was Yo.
His father was a netsuke (miniature carving attached to the end of a cord hanging from a pouch) artisan Kokusai (Sozo) OZAKI and mother was Yo.
His father was a netsuke (miniature carving attached to the end of a cord hanging from a pouch) artisan Kokusai (Sozo) OZAKI and his mother was Yo.
sen.cmt: motherの前にhisを挿入しました。

sen.j: もともと尾崎家は伊勢屋という商家であると推定されるが、惣蔵の代には既に廃業していたようである。
sen.e: It is assumed that the Ozaki family was used to be a house of merchant named Iseya, but it seems that Iseya had already been out of business by the generation of Sozo.
It is assumed that the Ozaki family used to be a house of merchants named Iseya, but it seems that Iseya had already been out of business by the time of the Sozo generation.
It is assumed that the Ozaki family used to be a house of merchants named Iseya, but it seems that Iseya had already been out of business by the time of the Sozo generation.

sen.j: 伊勢屋は呉服屋説と米問屋説があるが不明である。
sen.e: Some said that Iseya was a kimono fabrics shop while others said that it was a rice warehouse merchant, but the fact is unknown.
Some said that Iseya was a kimono fabric shop while others said that it was a rice warehouse merchant, but the actual fact is unknown.
Some said that Iseya was a kimono fabric shop while others said that it was a rice warehouse merchant, but the actual fact is unknown.

sen.j: 明治5年（1872年）、4歳で母と死別し、母方の祖父母荒木舜庵、せんのもとで育てられる。
sen.e: In 1872, Koyo lost his mother at the age of four and thereafter was brought up by his maternal grandparents, Shunan and Sen ARAKI.
In 1872, Koyo lost his mother at the age of four and was brought up by his maternal grandparents, Shunan and Sen ARAKI.
In 1872, Koyo lost his mother at the age of four and was brought up by his maternal grandparents, Shunan and Sen ARAKI.

sen.j: 寺子屋・梅泉堂（梅泉学校、のち港区立桜川小、現在の港区立御成門小学校）を経て、府第二中学（すぐに府第一中と統合し府中学となる。現在の東京都立日比谷高等学校）に進学。
sen.e: After graduated from terakoya (a private elementary school in the Edo period) named Baisendo (Baisen Primary School, later Sakuragawa elementary school, and present-day Onarimon elementary school in Minato Ward), Koyo went to Tokyofu Daini Junior High School (soon became Tokyofu Junior High School after merged with Tokyofu Dainichi Junior High School; present-day Hibiya High School, Tokyo).

After graduating from terakoya (a private elementary school during the Edo period) called Baisendo (Baisen Primary School, later Sakuragawa elementary school, and the present-day Onarimon elementary school in Minato Ward), Koyo went to Tokyofu Daini Junior High School (soon became Tokyofu Junior High School after merging with Tokyofu Dainichi Junior High School; present-day Hibiya High School, Tokyo).

After graduating from terakoya (a private elementary school during the Edo period) called Baisendo (Baisen Primary School, later Sakuragawa elementary school, and the present-day Onarimon elementary school in Minato Ward), Koyo went to Tokyofu Daini Junior High School (soon became Tokyofu Junior High School after merging with Tokyofu Dainichi Junior High School; present-day Hibiya High School, Tokyo).

sen.j: 一期生で、同級に幸田露伴、他に沢柳政太郎、狩野亨吉らがいたが、中退。
sen.e: Koyo was a member of the inaugural class together with Rohan KODA, Masataro SAWAYANAGI, and Kokichi KANO, but Koyo dropped out of the school.
Koyo was a member of the inaugural class together with Rohan KODA, Masataro SAWAYANAGI, and Kokichi KANO, but later Koyo dropped out of the school.
Koyo was a member of the inaugural class together with Rohan KODA, Masataro SAWAYANAGI, and Kokichi KANO, but later Koyo dropped out of the school.

sen.j: 岡千仭の綏猷堂で漢学を、石川鴻斎の崇文館で漢詩文を学んだほか、三田英学校で英語などを学び、第一高等学校 (旧制) 入学を目指した。
sen.e: He learned Sinology at Senjin OKA's Suiyudo and Chinese prose and poetry at Kosai ISHIKAWA's Subunkan in addition to English at Mita English School with the aim of entering Daiichi High School (the first old-education-system high school).
sen.cmt: 「錦城高等学校 (私立)」は現在の学校名なのでWeb表記にならい当時の名称「三田英学校」にしました。
sen.e: He learned Sinology at Senjin OKA's Suiyudo and Chinese prose and poetry at Kosai ISHIKAWA's Subunkan in addition to English at Mita English School with the aim of entering Daiichi High School (the first old-education-system high school).

He learned Sinology at Senjin OKA's Suiyudo and Chinese prose and poetry at Kosai ISHIKAWA's Subunkan in addition to English at Mita English School with the aim of entering Daiichi High School (the first old-education-system high school).

sen.j: 紅葉の学費を援助したのは、母方荒木家と関係の深い横尾家であった。
sen.e: Koyo's school expenses was paid by the Yokoo family which had a deep relationship with his maternal relatives the Araki family.
Koyo's school expenses were paid by the Yokoo family which had a deep relationship with his maternal relatives, the Araki family.
Koyo's school expenses were paid by the Yokoo family which had a deep relationship with his maternal relatives, the Araki family.

sen.j: 紅葉が明治32年（1899年）に佐渡に旅した際に新潟で立ち寄ったのが、大蔵官僚で当時新潟の税務署長をしていた横尾の伯父（母庸の姉婿）である。
sen.e: When Koyo made a trip to Sado in 1899, he visited Niigata to see his uncle Yokoo (his mother Yo's elder sister's husband) who was a bureaucrat at the Ministry of Treasury and the superintendent of a tax office in Niigata at that time.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When Koyo made a trip to Sado in 1899, he visited Niigata to see his uncle Yokoo (his mother Yo's elder sister's husband) who was a bureaucrat at the Ministry of the Treasury and the superintendent of a tax office in Niigata at that time.

When Koyo made a trip to Sado in 1899, he visited Niigata to see his uncle Yokoo (his mother Yo's elder sister's husband) who was a bureaucrat at the Ministry of the Treasury and the superintendent of a tax office in Niigata at that time.

sen.j: 紅葉の三女三千代は、荒木家（母庸の弟）に養女に出された後に、横尾の伯父の養子石夫（海軍）に嫁いでいる。
sen.e: Koyo's third daughter Michiyo was adopted by the Araki family (his mother Yo's elder brother) and later married Iwao, an adopted son of uncle Yokoo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Koyo's third daughter Michiyo was adopted by the Araki family (his mother Yo's elder brother) and later married Iwao, an adopted son of uncle Yokoo.
Koyo's third daughter Michiyo was adopted by the Araki family (his mother Yo's elder brother) and later married Iwao, an adopted son of uncle Yokoo.

sen.j: 石夫の実父（養父の兄）は内務官僚であったが、安濃郡長（島根県）の時に若くして亡くなった。
sen.e: Iwao's natural father (elder brother of foster father) was a bureaucrat at the Ministry of Interior but died young when he was the chief of Ano county (Shimane Prefecture).
Iwao's natural father (elder brother of foster father) was a bureaucrat at the Ministry of Interior but died young when he was the chief of Ano county (Shimane Prefecture).
Iwao's natural father (elder brother of foster father) was a bureaucrat at the Ministry of Interior but died young when he was the chief of Ano county (Shimane Prefecture).

sen.j: 石夫の弟に東京帝大医学部教授の安夫がいる。
sen.e: An elder brother of Iwao was Yasuo who became a professor of Faculty of Medicine, Tokyo Imperial University.
Iwao's elder brother Yasuo, became a professor of Faculty of Medicine, Tokyo Imperial University.
Iwao's younger brother Yasuo, became a professor of Faculty of Medicine, Tokyo Imperial University.

sen.j: 明治16年（1883年）に第一高等学校 (旧制)に入るが、それ以前から緑山と号して詩作にふけり、入学後は文友会、凸々会に参加し文学への関心を深めた。
sen.e: In 1883 Koyo entered the Daiichi High School; by that time, however, he was absorbed in writing poems with penname Enzan and after entering the high school he participated in literary groups such as Bunyukai and Totsutostukai to deepen his interest in literature.

In 1883 Koyo entered Daiichi High School; by that time, however, he was absorbed in writing poems under the penname of Enzan and after entering high school he participated in literary groups such as Bunyukai and Totsutostukai to deepen his interest in literature.

In 1883 Koyo entered Daiichi High School; by that time, however, he was absorbed in writing poems under the penname of Enzan and after entering high school he participated in literary groups such as Bunyukai and Totsutostukai to deepen his interest in literature.

sen.j: そして明治18年（1885年）、山田美妙、石橋思案、丸岡九華らとともに硯友社を結成、回覧雑誌『我楽多文庫』を発刊した。
sen.e: In 1885, he founded the Kenyusha with Bimyo YAMADA, Shian ISHIBASHI, Kyuka MARUOKA and others, and published a magazine for circulating "Garakuta Bunko" (Library of Mixtures).
In 1885, he founded Kenyusha with Bimyo YAMADA, Shian ISHIBASHI, Kyuka MARUOKA and others, and published a magazine for circulating "Garakuta Bunko" (Library of Mixtures).

sen.j: 最初は肉筆筆写の雑誌だったが、好評のために活版化するようになった。
sen.e: At first the magazine was made and copied in handwriting, but later printed with type as it became popular.
At first the magazine was made and copied in handwriting, but later printed with type as it became popular.
At first the magazine was made and copied in handwriting, but later printed with type as it became popular.

sen.j: 明治21年（1888年）、『我楽多文庫』を販売することになり、そこに「風流京人形」を連載、注目を浴びるようになる。
sen.e: In 1888, "Garakuta Bunko" went on the market and Koyo run a serialized novel "Furyu Kyoto ningyo" (The Elegant Kyoto Doll) which attracted much attention.
In 1888, "Garakuta Bunko" went on the market and Koyo ran a serialized novel "Furyu Kyoto ningyo" (The Elegant Kyoto Doll) that attracted much attention.
In 1888, "Garakuta Bunko" went on the market and Koyo ran a serialized novel 'Furyu Kyo ningyo' (The Elegant Kyoto Doll) that attracted much attention.
sen.cmt: "Furyu Kyoto ningyo"を 'Furyu Kyo ningyo'に変更しました。

sen.j: しかしその年、美妙は新しく出る雑誌『都の花』の主筆に迎えられることとなり、紅葉と縁を絶つことになった。
sen.e: In the same year, however, Bimyo was appointed to the chief editor of new magazine "Miyako no hana" and severed his relations with Koyo.
In the same year, however, Bimyo was appointed to the chief editor of a new magazine "Miyako no hana" and severed his relations with Koyo.
In the same year, however, Bimyo was appointed to the chief editor of a new magazine "Miyako no hana" and severed his relations with Koyo.

sen.j: 明治22年（1889年）、「我楽多文庫」を刊行していた吉岡書店が、新しく小説の書き下ろし叢書を出すことになった。
sen.e: In 1889, the publisher of "Garakuta Bunko" Yoshioka Shoten started a new series of newly-written novels.
In 1889, the publisher of "Garakuta Bunko" Yoshioka Shoten started a new series of newly-written novels.
In 1889, the publisher of 'Garakuta Bunko' Yoshioka Shoten started a new series of newly-written novels.

sen.j: 「新著百種」と名づけられたそのシリーズの第1冊目として、紅葉の『二人比丘尼 色懺悔』が刊行された。
sen.e: As the first book of the series called "Shincho Hyakushu," Koyo's "Ninin bikuni irozange" (Amorous Confessions of Two Nuns) was published.
As the first book of the series called "Shincho Hyakushu," Koyo's "Ninin bikuni irozange" (Amorous Confessions of Two Nuns) was published.

sen.cmt: 原文「」の部分を' 'に変更しました。

sen.j: 戦国時代に材をとり、戦で死んだ若武者を弔う二人の女性の邂逅というストーリーと、会話を口語体にしながら、地の文は流麗な文語文という雅俗折衷の文体とが、当時の新しい文学のあらわれとして好評を博し、紅葉は一躍流行作家として世間に迎えられた。
sen.e: The story situated in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) with two women who were mourning for young warriors died in the battle happened to meet each other, and its gazoku-setchu style, i.e. the mixture of dialogue in common language and narrative in elegant literary style received favorable reviews as the symbol of new style of contemporary literature, so Koyo suddenly because famous as a popular writer.

The story situated during the Sengoku period (period of warring states) with two women who were mourning for young warriors that died in battle happened to meet each other, and its gazoku-setchu style, i.e. the mixture of dialogue in common language and narrative in elegant literary style received favorable reviews as the symbol of new style of contemporary literature, so Koyo suddenly became famous as a popular writer.

The story situated during the Sengoku period (period of warring states) with two women who were mourning for young warriors that died in battle happened to meet each other, and its gazoku-setchu style, i.e. the mixture of dialogue in common language and narrative in elegant literary style received favorable reviews as the symbol of new style of contemporary literature, so Koyo suddenly became famous as a popular writer.

sen.j: このころ井原西鶴に熱中しその作品に傾倒、写実主義とともに擬古典主義を深めるようになる。
sen.e: At that time, he was absorbed in reading Saikaku IHARA's works that encouraged his inclination to pseudoclassicism in addition to realism.
At that time, he was absorbed in reading Saikaku IHARA's works that encouraged his inclination to pseudoclassicism in addition to realism.

sen.j: 一方、大学予備門の学制改革により、明治19年（1886年）に第一高等中学校英語政治科に編入。
sen.e: At the same time, due to educational system reform of Preparatory School of the University of Tokyo (Tokyo Yobimon), he was transferred to Daiichi Koto Chugakko (First High School) School of English Politics in 1886.

At the same time, due to educational system reform of the Preparatory School of the University of Tokyo (Tokyo Yobimon), he was transferred to Daiichi Koto Chugakko (First High School) School of English Politics in 1886.

sen.j: 明治21年（1888年）、帝国大学法科大学政治科に入学、同22年（1889年）に国文科に転科し、翌年退学した。
sen.e: In 1888 he entered Imperial University School of Law the department of Politics; in 1889 he transferred to the department of Japanese literature; in the following year, he dropped out of the school.

In 1888 he entered the Imperial University School of Law the department of Politics; in 1889 he transferred to the department of Japanese literature; in the following year, he dropped out of the school.

sen.j: この前年の末に、大学在学中ながら読売新聞に入社し、以後紅葉の作品の重要な発表舞台は読売新聞となる。
sen.e: At the end of the previous year, he joined the Yomiuri Shimbun (a daily newspaper) while attending the university; since then, the newspaper was his primary medium to publish his works.
At the end of the previous year, he joined the Yomiuri Shimbun (a daily newspaper) while attending the university; since then, the newspaper was his primary medium for publishing his works.

sen.j: 「伽羅枕」「三人妻」などを載せ、高い人気を得た。
sen.e: His novels such as "Kyara makura" and "Sanninzuma" (Three Wives) appeared in the newspaper and gained high popularity.
His novels such as "Kyara makura" and "Sanninzuma" (Three Wives) appeared in the newspaper and gained high popularity.
His novels such as 'Kyara makura' and 'Sanninzuma' (Three Wives) appeared in the newspaper and gained high popularity.

sen.j: このほか「である」の言文一致を途中から試みた「二人女房」などを発表、幸田露伴とともに明治期の文壇の重鎮となり、この時期は紅露時代と呼ばれた。
sen.e: He also published "Futari Nyobo" (Two Wives) in which he tried the vernacular style with "dearu" ending of sentences from the middle of the story, and these achievements made him one of the leaders of literary circle in the Meiji Period along with Rohan KODA, thus this period was called Ko-Ro Jidai (the era of Koyo and Rohan).

He also published "Futari Nyobo" (Two Wives) in which he tried the vernacular style with "dearu" ending of sentences from the middle of the story, and these achievements made him one of the leaders of literary circles during the Meiji Period along with Rohan KODA, so, this period was called Ko-Ro Jidai (the era of Koyo and Rohan).

He also published 'Futari Nyobo' (Two Wives) in which he tried the vernacular style with 'dearu' ending of sentences from the middle of the story, and these achievements made him one of the leaders of literary circles during the Meiji Period along with Rohan KODA, so, this period was called Ko-Ro Jidai (the era of Koyo and Rohan).

sen.j: 明治28年（1895年）、『源氏物語』を読み、その影響を受け心理描写に主を置き『多情多恨』などを書いた。
sen.e: In 1895, he read "Genji Monogatari" (The Tale of Genji) and under the influence of this tale he wrote novels focusing on psychological descriptions such as "Tajo Takon."

sen.j: そして明治30年（1897年）、「金色夜叉」の連載が『読売新聞』で始まる。
sen.e: Finally in 1897, a serialized novel "Konjiki Yasha" started appearing in the Yomiuri Shimbun.
Finally in 1897, a serialized novel "Konjiki Yasha" started appearing in the Yomiuri Shimbun.
Finally in 1897, a serialized novel 'Konjiki Yasha' started appearing in the Yomiuri Shimbun.

sen.j: 貫一とお宮をめぐっての金と恋の物語は日清戦争後の社会を背景にしていて、これが時流と合い大人気作となった。
sen.e: The story of money and love between Kanichi and Omiya matched the social background after the Japanese-Sino War and gained the wide popularity.
The story of money and love between Kanichi and Omiya matched the social background after the Japanese-Sino War and gained wide spread popularity.
The story of money and love between Kanichi and Omiya matched the social background after the Japanese-Sino War and gained wide spread popularity.

sen.j: 以後断続的に書かれることになるが、もともと病弱であったためこの長期連載が災いし、明治32年（1899年）から健康を害した。
sen.e: The story appeared in the newspaper intermittently, but Koyo's ill health became deteriorated because of this long serialized novel, and in 1899 he was taken with illness.
The story appeared in the newspaper intermittently, but Koyo's health deteriorated because of this long serialized novel, and in 1899 he became ill.
The story appeared in the newspaper intermittently, but Koyo's health deteriorated because of this long serialized novel, and in 1899 he became ill.

sen.j: 療養のために塩原町や修禅寺に赴き、明治36年（1903年）に『金色夜叉』の続編を連載（『続々金色夜叉』として刊行）したが、3月、胃癌と診断され中断。
sen.e: He went to Shiobara or Shuzenji for medical treatment and started writing the sequel of "Konjiki Yasha" in 1903 (published as "Zoku Zoku (continued continuation) Konjiki Yasha") but this serialized novel was suspended in March when he was diagnosed as stomach cancer.

He went to Shiobara or Shuzenji for medical treatment and began writing the sequel "Konjiki Yasha" in 1903 (published as "Zoku Zoku, or continued continuation, Konjiki Yasha") but this serialized novel was suspended in March when he was diagnosed with stomach cancer.

He went to Shiobara or Shuzenji for medical treatment and began writing the sequel "Konjiki Yasha" in 1903 (published as "Zoku Zoku, or continued continuation, Konjiki Yasha") but this serialized novel was suspended in March when he was diagnosed with stomach cancer.

sen.j: 10月30日、自宅で没した。
sen.e: On October 30, he died at his own house.
On October 30, he died in his own house.
On October 30, he died in his own house.

sen.j: 紅葉の墓は青山墓地にあるが、その揮毫は、硯友社の同人でもある親友巌谷小波の父で明治の三大書家の一人といわれた巌谷一六によるものである。
sen.e: Koyo's grave is in the Aoyama-bochi Cemetery and the tomb is inscribed with writing with a brush by Ichiroku IWAYA, one of the three greatest calligrapher in the Meiji Period who was the father of Sazanami IWAYA, Koyo's best friend and a member of Kenyusha.

Koyo's grave is in Aoyama-bochi Cemetery and his tomb is inscribed with brush style writing by Ichiroku IWAYA, one of the three greatest calligraphers during the Meiji Period who was the father of Sazanami IWAYA, Koyo's best friend and a member of Kenyusha.

Koyo's grave is in Aoyama-bochi Cemetery and his tomb is inscribed with brush style writing by Ichiroku IWAYA, one of the three greatest calligraphers during the Meiji Period who was the father of Sazanami IWAYA, Koyo's best friend and a member of Kenyusha.

sen.j: なお巌谷家は近江国水口藩（滋賀県甲賀市）藩医の家柄であるが、尾崎・横尾家と巌谷家の代々の関係が、安濃郡長の横尾石夫の実父に始まるものかは未だ不明である。
sen.e: The Iwaya family came from the clan of doctors served the Minakuchi Domain, Omi Province (Koga City, Shiga Prefecture) but it is still unknown whether the relationship between the Ozaki/Yokoo family and Iwaya family for generations started from the natural father of Iwao Yokoo who was the chief of Ano county.

The Iwaya family came from the clan of doctors served the Minakuchi Domain, Omi Province (Koga City, Shiga Prefecture) but it is still unknown whether the relationship between the Ozaki/Yokoo family and Iwaya family for generations started from the natural father of Iwao Yokoo who was the chief of Ano county.

The Iwaya family came from the clan of doctors served the Minakuchi Domain, Omi Province (Koga City, Shiga Prefecture) but it is still unknown whether the relationship between the Ozaki/Yokoo family and Iwaya family for generations started from the natural father of Iwao Yokoo who was the chief of Ano county.

sen.j: 作家評
sen.e: Reputation as novelist
Reputation as novelist
Reputation as a novelist

sen.j: 紅葉の作品は、その華麗な文章によって世に迎えられ、欧化主義に批判的な潮流から、井原西鶴を思わせる風俗描写の巧みさによって評価された。
sen.e: Koyo's novels were favorably received by the public for their elegant style and valued by those who were critical of Europeanism for the skillful descriptions of customs and manners that reminded them Saikaku IHARA.

Koyo's novels were favorably received by the public for their elegant style and valued by those who were critical of Europeanism for the skillful descriptions of customs and manners that reminded them of Saikaku IHARA.

Koyo's novels were favorably received by the public for their elegant style and valued by those who were critical of Europeanism for the skillful descriptions of customs and manners that reminded them of Saikaku IHARA.

sen.j: しかし一方では、北村透谷のように、「伽羅枕」に見られる古い女性観を批判する批評家もあった。
sen.e: On the other hand, some critics such as Tokoku KITAMURA criticized Koyo's old-fashioned view of women that was found in "Kyara makura."
On the other hand, some critics such as Tokoku KITAMURA criticized Koyo's old-fashioned view of women that was found in "Kyara makura."
On the other hand, some critics such as Tokoku KITAMURA criticized Koyo's old-fashioned view of women that was found in 'Kyara makura.'

sen.j: 国木田独歩は、その前半期は「洋装せる元禄文学」であったと述べた。
sen.e: Doppo KUNIKIDA reviewed that the first half of Koyo's career could be described as "literature of Genroku era (in Edo Period) dressed in European style."
Doppo KUNIKIDA said the first half of Koyo's career could be described as "literature from the Genroku era (during the Edo Period) in European style."
Doppo KUNIKIDA said the first half of Koyo's career could be described as 'literature from the Genroku era (during the Edo Period) in European style.'

sen.j: 山田美妙の言文一致体が「です・ます」調であることに対抗して、「である」の文体を試みたこともあったが、それは彼の作品の中では主流にはならなかった。
sen.e: In rivalry with Bimyo YAMADA's "desu-masu" vernacular style, Koyo attempted to use "dearu" style, but this style didn't become the mainstream of his works.
In rivalry with Bimyo YAMADA's "desu-masu" vernacular style, Koyo attempted to use the "dearu" style, but this style didn't become the mainstream part of his works.
In rivalry with Bimyo YAMADA's 'desu-masu' vernacular style, Koyo attempted to use the 'dearu' style, but this style didn't become the mainstream part of his works.

sen.j: ただし、後年の傑作『多情多恨』では、言文一致体による内面描写が成功している。
sen.e: In his masterpiece in his later years "Tajo Takon," however, he had a success in psychological description in vernacular style.
In his masterpiece in his later years "Tajo Takon," he had achieved success in psychological description in a vernacular style.
In his masterpiece in his later years "Tajo Takon," he had achieved success in psychological description in a vernacular style.

sen.j: 紅葉は英語力に優れ、イギリスの百科事典『ブリタニカ』を内田魯庵の丸善が売り出したときに、最初に売れた3部のうちのひとつは紅葉が買ったものだったという。
sen.e: Koyo had a high level of proficiency in English; there was an anecdote that when Roan UCHIDA's Maruzen Company started selling the Encyclopedia Britannica, Koyo was one of the first three buyers.
Koyo had a high level of proficiency in English; there was a story that when Roan UCHIDA's Maruzen Company started selling the Encyclopedia Britannica, Koyo was one of the first three buyers.
Koyo had a high level of proficiency in English; there was a story that when Roan UCHIDA's Maruzen Company started selling the Encyclopedia "Britannica", Koyo was one of the first three buyers.
sen.cmt: 原文『』の部分に" "を付加しました。

sen.j: その英語力で、英米の大衆小説を大量に読み、それを翻案して自作の骨子としてとりいれたものも多い。
sen.e: With such proficiency in English, He read a huge amount of English popular fiction and the framework of many of his novels were adopted from these English novels.
With such proficiency in English, He read a huge amount of English popular fiction and the framework of many of his novels were adopted from these English novels.
With such proficiency in English, He read a huge amount of English popular fiction and the framework of many of his novels were adopted from these English novels.

sen.j: 晩年の作『金色夜叉』の粉本として、バーサ・クレイの『女より弱きもの』が堀啓子によって指摘された。
sen.e: Keiko HORI pointed out that Koyo modeled his work in his later years "Konjiki Yasha" on "Weaker Than a Woman" by Bertha M. Clay.
Keiko HORI pointed out that Koyo modeled his work in his later years "Konjiki Yasha" on "Weaker Than a Woman" by Bertha M. Clay.
Keiko HORI pointed out that Koyo modeled his work in his later years "Konjiki Yasha" on "Weaker Than a Woman" by Bertha M. Clay.

sen.j: 年譜
sen.e: Chronological list of the main events
Chronological list of main events

sen.j: ※日付は明治4年までは旧暦
sen.e: * Dates are according to the old lunar calendar up to 1871.
* Dates are according to the old lunar calendar up to 1871.
* Dates are according to the old lunar calendar up to 1871.

sen.j: 慶応3年（1867年）12月16日 (旧暦)、江戸芝に生れる。
sen.e: Born in Shiba, Edo in December 16, 1867 (the old calendar).
Born in Shiba, Edo in December 16, 1867 (the old calendar).
Born in Shiba, Edo in December 16, 1867 (the old calendar).

sen.j: 明治16年（1883年）9月、第一高等学校 (旧制)に入学。
sen.e: In September 1883, entered the Daiichi High School (the first old-education-system high school)
In September 1883, entered Daiichi High School (the first old-education-system high school)
In September 1883, entered Daiichi High School (the first old-education-system high school)

sen.j: 2月、硯友社を結成。
sen.e: In February, formed Kenyusha.
In February, formed Kenyusha.
In February, formed Kenyusha.

sen.j: 5月、「我楽多文庫」を発刊。
sen.e: In May, published "Garakuta Bunko."
In May, published "Garakuta Bunko."
In May, published 'Garakuta Bunko.'

sen.j: 明治20年（1887年）4月、東京女子専門学校で漢学の教師のアルバイトをする。
sen.e: In April 1887, worked part time as a teacher of Chinese classics at Tokyo Girls Vocational School.
In April 1887, worked part time as a teacher of Chinese classics at Tokyo Girls Vocational School.
In April 1887, worked part time as a teacher of Chinese classics at Tokyo Girls Vocational School.

sen.j: 4月、『二人比丘尼 色懺悔』を刊行。
sen.e: In April, published "Ninin bikuni irozange."
In April, published "Ninin bikuni irozange."
In April, published "Ninin bikuni irozange."

sen.j: 12月、読売新聞に入社。
sen.e: In December joined the Yomiuri Shimbun.
In December joined the Yomiuri Shimbun.
In December joined the Yomiuri Shimbun.

sen.j: 明治23年（1890年）帝国大学を退学。
sen.e: In 1890, dropped out of the Tokyo Imperial University.
In 1890, dropped out of Tokyo Imperial University.
In 1890, dropped out of Tokyo Imperial University.

sen.j: 明治24年（1891年）3月10日、樺島喜久と結婚。
sen.e: On March 10, 1891, married to Kiku Kabashima.
On March 10, 1891, married Kiku Kabashima.
On March 10, 1891, married Kiku Kabashima.

sen.j: 明治25年（1892年）3月、「三人妻」を『読売新聞』に連載。
sen.e: In March 1892, a serialized novel "Sanninzuma" appeared in the Yomiuri Shimbun.
In March 1892, the serialized novel "Sanninzuma" appeared in the Yomiuri Shimbun.
In March 1892, the serialized novel 'Sanninzuma' appeared in the "Yomiuri Shimbun."

sen.j: 1月10日、長男弓之助が生れる（早逝）。
sen.e: On January 10, the first son Yuminosuke was born (who died young).
On January 10, the first son Yuminosuke was born (who died young).
On January 10, the first son Yuminosuke was born (who died young).

sen.j: 6月、「心の闇」を『読売新聞』に連載。
sen.e: In June, a serialized novel "Kokoro no yami" appeared in the Yomiuri Shimbun.
In June, a serialized novel "Kokoro no yami" appeared in the Yomiuri Shimbun.
In June, a serialized novel 'Kokoro no yami' appeared in the "Yomiuri Shimbun."

sen.j: 2月3日、長女藤枝が生れる。
sen.e: On February 3, the first daughter Fujie was born.
On February 3, his first daughter Fujie was born.
On February 3, his first daughter Fujie was born.

sen.j: 同21日、父惣蔵死去。
sen.e: On February 21, his father Sozo died.
On February 21, his father Sozo died.
On February 21, his father Sozo died.

sen.j: 2月、「多情多恨」を『読売新聞』に連載。
sen.e: In February, a serialized novel "Tajo Takon" appeared in the Yomiuri Shimbun.
In February, a serialized novel "Tajo Takon" appeared in the Yomiuri Shimbun.

sen.j: 3月10日、次女弥生が生れる。
sen.e: On March 10, the second daughter Yayoi was born.
On March 10, the second daughter Yayoi was born.
On March 10, the second daughter Yayoi was born.

sen.j: 明治30年（1897年）1月、「金色夜叉」を『読売新聞』に連載。
sen.e: In January 1897, a serialized novel "Konjiki Yasha" appeared in the Yomiuri Shimbun.
In January 1897, the serialized novel "Konjiki Yasha" appeared in the Yomiuri Shimbun.

sen.j: 明治32年（1899年）、健康を害する。
sen.e: In 1899, his health became deteriorated.
In 1899, his health deteriorated.
In 1899, his health deteriorated.

sen.j: 6月に塩原、7月から8月にかけて新潟へ赴く。
sen.e: He went to Shiobara in June and Niigata in July to August.
He went to Shiobara in June and Niigata from July to August.
He went to Shiobara in June and Niigata from July to August.

sen.j: 明治33年（1900年）3月26日、三女三千代が生れる。
sen.e: On March 26, 1900, the third daughter Michiyo was born.
On March 26, 1900, his third daughter Michiyo was born.
On March 26, 1900, his third daughter Michiyo was born.

sen.j: 5月、療養のために修善寺へ赴く。
sen.e: In May, went to Shuzenji for medical treatment.
In May, went to Shuzenji for medical treatment.
In May, went to Shuzenji for medical treatment.

sen.j: 同20日、次男夏彦が生れる。
sen.e: On May 20, the second son Natsuhiko was born.
On May 20, his second son Natsuhiko was born.
On May 20, his second son Natsuhiko was born.

sen.j: 明治35年（1902年）、読売新聞社を退社し、二六新報に入社。
sen.e: In 1902, resigned from the Yomiuri Shimbun and joined the Nirokushimpo.
In 1902, resigned from the Yomiuri Shimbun and joined the Nirokushimpo.
In 1902, resigned from the Yomiuri Shimbun and joined the Nirokushimpo.

sen.j: 明治36年（1903年）10月30日、牛込区横井町の自宅で死去。
sen.e: On October 30, 1903, died at his own house in Yokoicho, Ushigome.
On October 30, 1903, died in his own house in Yokoicho, Ushigome.
On October 30, 1903, died in his own house in Yokoicho, Ushigome.

sen.j: 門下生
sen.e: Disciples
Disciples
Disciples

sen.j: 20歳代で多くの弟子を抱えた。
sen.e: He had many disciples while he was still in his twenties.
He had many disciples while he was still in his twenties.
He had many disciples while he was still in his twenties.

sen.j: 特に泉鏡花、徳田秋声、小栗風葉、柳川春葉の四人は藻門下（紅葉門下）四天王と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Among them, Kyoka IZUMI, Shusei TOKUDA, Fuyo OGURI, and Shunyo YANAGAWA were referred to as the Shitenno (the four heavenly kings).
Among them, Kyoka IZUMI, Shusei TOKUDA, Fuyo OGURI, and Shunyo YANAGAWA were referred to as the Shitenno (the four heavenly kings).
Among them, Kyoka IZUMI, Shusei TOKUDA, Fuyo OGURI, and Shunyo YANAGAWA were referred to as the Shitenno (the four heavenly kings).

sen.j: このような肌合いがちがう弟子たちをうまくまとめることができたところに紅葉の人徳がある。
sen.e: It was Koyo's personal magnetism that enabled to gather together those disciples with different characters.
It was Koyo's personal magnetism that enabled him to gather together those disciples with different character.
It was Koyo's personal magnetism that enabled him to gather together those disciples with different character.

sen.j: その点では、同時代の文学者たちの中で、出色であったといえよう。
sen.e: This charisma made Koyo an outstanding figure among his contemporary authors.
This charisma made Koyo an outstanding figure among his contemporary authors.
This charisma made Koyo an outstanding figure among his contemporary authors.

sen.j: 芝神明榮太樓の銘菓「江の嶋」最中は、明治35年2月に紅葉が名づけ題字を認めたものであり、紅葉の本を装丁した武内桂舟の下絵とともに今でも用いられており、現在まで続くロングセラー商品となっている。
sen.e: A long-established confectionery in Shibashinmeicho Eitaro's famous sweet "Enoshima" monaka (bean-jam-filled wafers) was named by Koyo in February 1902 and he allowed the shop to use his handwritings on the package with illustration by Keishu TAKEUCHI, an illustrator of Koyo's books, and this package is still used today for the long-seller "Enoshima."

A long-established confectionery in Shibashinmeicho Eitaro's famous sweet "Enoshima" monaka (bean-jam-filled wafers) was named by Koyo in February 1902 and he allowed the shop to use his handwriting on the package with an illustration by Keishu TAKEUCHI, an illustrator of Koyo's books, and this package is still used today for the long-seller "Enoshima."

A long-established confectionery in Shibashinmei Eitaro's famous sweet 'Enoshima' monaka (bean-jam-filled wafers) was named by Koyo in February 1902 and he allowed the shop to use his handwriting on the package with an illustration by Keishu TAKEUCHI, an illustrator of Koyo's books, and this package is still used today for the long-seller 'Enoshima.'

sen.j: 芝神明町は、母庸が若くして亡くなった後、紅葉を育てた医者の祖父荒木舜庵の家があった場所である。
sen.e: Shibashinmei-cho is a place where his grandfather and a doctor Shunan ARAKI lived who raised Koyo after his mother died young.
Shibashinmei-cho is a place where his grandfather and doctor Shunan ARAKI lived who raised Koyo after his mother died young.

sen.j: 紅葉の最期の言葉は、見舞いに来た人々の泣いているのを見て言った、「どいつもまずい面だ」だったという。
sen.e: Koyo's last word was "Each one of you has an ugly face" by looking at crying visitors.
Koyo's last word was "Each one of you has an ugly face" while looking at the crying visitors.
